questions.text: The most reliable criteria in Gustafson’s method of identification is
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transparency of root is the most reliable criteria in Gustafson’s method for determining age in forensic investigations. Gustafson’s method assesses multiple age-related changes in teeth but is most effective when root transparency is emphasized.
  • ➤ Transparency of root is the most reliable criteria in Gustafson’s method for determining age in forensic investigations.
  • ➤ Gustafson’s method assesses multiple age-related changes in teeth but is most effective when root transparency is emphasized.

questions.text: Which of the following method is based on age determination based on weight and height of the erupting teeth?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stack’s method is used for age determination in infants based on the weight and height of erupting teeth and is not applicable for older children or adults.
  • ➤ Stack’s method is used for age determination in infants based on the weight and height of erupting teeth

questions.text: The age of eruption of first deciduous molar teeth:
questions.explanation: Ans. C) 12-14 months

questions.text: Number of teeth at 7 years:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 24

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that at 7 years, a child usually has around 24 teeth, including a mix of primary and permanent teeth, with the number of permanent teeth roughly estimated by the formula (age - 5) × 4.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child's remains are discovered in a secluded area, and a forensic team is tasked with the investigation. Given the state of decomposition, the team faces challenges in establishing the child's exact age at the time of death, which is crucial for the ongoing investigation. The forensic expert, aware of the importance of skeletal development in age estimation for children, decides to focus on specific joints for examination. In the context of a child between 2 to 6 years old, which joint would the forensic expert prioritize to provide the most accurate age estimation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Wrist joint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wrist joint as the key anatomical site for the estimation of age in children between 2 to 6 years old, utilizing the appearance and fusion of multiple ossification centers.
  • ➤ Wrist joint as the key anatomical site for the estimation of age in children between 2 to 6 years old, utilizing the appearance and fusion of multiple ossification centers.
  • ➤ NOTE : X-rays of elbow, wrist, clavicle and shoulder joints (upper extremity) and hip, knee and ankle joints (lower extremity) are usually recommended to determine the age before 25 years of age. If all the epiphyses of all the long bones are united, the person is most probably over 25 years of age.
  • ➤ NOTE

questions.text: A forensic researcher is conducting a population study on fingerprint patterns to determine which type is most commonly observed in individuals. Among the following fingerprint types, which one is most frequently found?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A person is accused of committing Rape. He claims to be adolescent. He is brought to the government hospital for age estimation to determine if he should be sent to juvenile home or an adult jail. The X-ray image of the pelvis is shown below. What is the age?
questions.explanation: Ans. C. 17-18 years

questions.text: What is the age of abrasion?
questions.explanation: Ans. D. > 7 days

questions.text: Injury shown in the image is a:
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Laceration

questions.text: The image below is seen in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Windshield glass injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Windshield glass injuries commonly occur in car accidents and present as multiple superficial lacerations, also known as "sparrow feet" marks. These injuries are most often seen in drivers and front-seat passengers due to their proximity to the windshield.

questions.text: Tailing of the Incised wound helps to know?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Direction of the wound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tailing in an incised wound is an indication of the direction of the wound , with the deeper end representing the starting point and the shallower end indicating the finishing point.
  • ➤ Tailing in an incised wound is an indication of the direction of the wound

questions.text: Which type of pedestrian injury is caused by the initial contact with the vehicle?
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Primary impact injury

questions.text: A man fell from 35 feet height. Eyewitnesses say that he landed on his feet. Which of the following injuries is possible:

options.label: A
options.text: Ring fracture of Foramen magnum + Lumbar spine injury

options.label: B
options.text: Pond fracture skull + Cervical spine injury

options.label: C
options.text: Gutter fracture skull + Cervical spine injury

options.label: D
options.text: Depressed fracture skull + Cervical spine injury

questions.correct_answer: A. Ring fracture of Foramen magnum + Lumbar spine injury
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ring fracture of Foramen magnum + Lumbar spine injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of falls from a height where the person lands on their feet or buttocks , the force is transmitted vertically, leading to the possibility of a ring fracture of the foramen magnum and injuries to the lumbar spine . Understanding how force travels through the body during different types of trauma is crucial for identifying possible injuries
  • ➤ feet or buttocks
  • ➤ ring fracture of the foramen magnum
  • ➤ lumbar spine

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is found dead in his apartment with multiple stab wounds. Forensic analysis reveals that some wounds are superficial while others are deep and fatal. The presence of bruising around the deeper wounds indicates they were inflicted while the victim was still alive. During the medicolegal investigation, it is crucial to determine the sequence of injuries. Which of the following findings would most likely indicate the initial phase of the assault?

options.label: A
options.text: The depth and location of the fatal wounds

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of defensive wounds on the hands and arms

options.label: C
options.text: The pattern of blood splatter in the room

options.label: D
options.text: The degree of bruising around the superficial wounds

questions.correct_answer: B. The presence of defensive wounds on the hands and arms
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The presence of defensive wounds on the hands and arms

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The significance of defensive wounds : These injuries are critical for reconstructing the sequence of events in a violent assault. Recognizing and interpreting such findings is essential in medicolegal investigations, particularly in cases involving criminal acts, to provide a detailed and accurate account of the incident.
  • ➤ The significance of defensive wounds : These injuries are critical for reconstructing the sequence of events in a violent assault.
  • ➤ The significance of defensive wounds
  • ➤ Recognizing and interpreting such findings is essential in medicolegal investigations, particularly in cases involving criminal acts, to provide a detailed and accurate account of the incident.

questions.text: During the autopsy, the forensic expert observes a distinct pattern of wounds on the neck of a deceased individual. These wounds appear shallow and hesitantly self-inflicted, with evidence of hesitation and uncertainty during the act. what is the significance of such hesitation wounds?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Suicide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Hesitation cuts/tentative cuts - They are parallel superficial cuts suggestive of suicidal motive , seen in the vital parts of the body such as neck, wrists , etc. They are inflicted by the victim, prior to the final fatal deep cut e.g. suicidal cut-throat wound.
  • • Hesitation cuts/tentative cuts -
  • • parallel superficial cuts suggestive of suicidal motive
  • • vital parts of the body such as neck, wrists
  • • inflicted by the victim, prior to the final fatal deep cut
  • • Initially the victim is hesitant hence he is able to inflict only superficial cuts; then finally he is able make a deep fatal wound. They indicate suicide.
  • • The below image shows Suicidal cut-throat wound with hesitation cuts:
  • • The below image shows Homicidal cut-throat wound without hesitation cuts:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hesitation wounds , characterized by shallow and hesitant self-inflicted injuries , are often encountered in cases of suicide . These wounds reflect the individual's uncertainty and hesitation during the act of self-harm.
  • ➤ Hesitation wounds
  • ➤ shallow and hesitant self-inflicted injuries
  • ➤ encountered in cases of suicide
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 194; NG Rao, 2/e, pg 229
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Reddy 33/e. Pg 194; NG Rao, 2/e, pg 229

questions.text: Defence wounds on a dead body suggest?
Avulsion is a type of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) laceration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Avulsion is a type of laceration resulting from blunt trauma that causes a portion of skin and underlying tissue to be partially or completely torn away, often seen in cases involving rotational or shearing forces, such as in road traffic accidents.

questions.text: Small injury causing big size bruise:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Face

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Small injuries can result in large bruises in areas with loose and vascular tissue, such as the face, vulva, and scrotum, where blood spreads easily due to less supportive tissue structure.

questions.text: Bumper fracture is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Primary impact injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A bumper fracture is considered a primary impact injury, occurring at the first contact point between a vehicle’s bumper and the pedestrian’s leg, often resulting in a fracture of the tibia or fibula.

questions.text: All are components of gun-powder EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Lead peroxide

questions.text: The distance between the victim and firearm in the below image?
questions.explanation: Ans. D. 2m-4m

questions.text: The following is a victim of a firearm injury. What is the suspected distance of the shot?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Intermediate range

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ENTRY WOUND FEATURES
  • ➤ ENTRY WOUND FEATURES
  • ➤ Contact (tight contact): Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible. Close Contact (Close Range contact/Point Blank/Loose contact/Near contact # ): Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent) Intermediate Range/Near range # /Medium Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound Distant range/Long Range: None of these present around the wound.
  • ➤ Contact (tight contact): Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  • ➤ Contact (tight contact):
  • ➤ Close Contact (Close Range contact/Point Blank/Loose contact/Near contact # ): Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  • ➤ Close Contact (Close Range contact/Point Blank/Loose contact/Near contact # ):
  • ➤ Intermediate Range/Near range # /Medium Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  • ➤ Intermediate Range/Near range # /Medium Range:
  • ➤ Distant range/Long Range: None of these present around the wound.
  • ➤ Distant range/Long Range:
  • ➤ # Near Contact and Near range are different.

questions.text: If a victims’ gunshot entry and exit wound are not properly distinguishable during post-mortem due to corrective surgery, it is known as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kennedy phenomenon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Kennedy phenomenon describes the challenge of identifying gunshot entry and exit wounds in post-mortem examinations due to surgical alterations, named after the case of President John F. Kennedy.

questions.text: During a forensic examination, a pathologist investigates a deceased individual with distinct marks on the body. The victim presents with petechial hemorrhages in the eyes, cyanosis of the nails, and bruising in the shape of a hand around the neck. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Throttling

questions.text: A man is killed by his brother over a property dispute. In post-mortem examination, a finding similar to the one shown in this radiological picture is seen. What could be the most possible cause of death?
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Throttling

questions.text: The image below indicates?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Typical hanging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Typical hanging is identified by a V-shaped, oblique ligature mark caused by the knot's position at the nape of the neck, consistent with gravitational forces.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male prisoner, sentenced to death, underwent execution by judicial hanging. The execution was performed with a calculated drop length. Upon autopsy, the forensic expert observed a specific finding with no signs of struggle or defensive injuries. Considering the mechanism of death in judicial hangings and the autopsy findings, what is the most likely cause of death in this case?
questions.correct_answer: C. Fracture of upper cervical vertebra
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fracture of upper cervical vertebra

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Airway occlusion : While this can occur in hangings , it is not the primary mechanism in judicial hanging , which aims for a quick fracture of the neck.
  • • Option A:
  • • Airway occlusion
  • • can occur in hangings
  • • it is not the primary mechanism
  • • judicial hanging
  • • Option B: Vasovagal shock : This is a less likely primary cause of death in judicial hangings , as the mechanism is designed to be quick and efficient.
  • • Option B:
  • • Vasovagal shock
  • • primary cause of death in judicial hangings
  • • Option D: Coma : Coma may result from the injury , but it is not the primary mechanism of death in judicial hanging.
  • • Option D:
  • • Coma
  • • result from the injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Judicial hanging typically results in death due to the fracture of the upper cervical vertebrae , leading to immediate unconsciousness and rapid death due to spinal cord injury and brainstem disruption.
  • ➤ Judicial hanging typically results in death due to the fracture of the upper cervical vertebrae
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 339
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ - Reddy 33/e. Pg 339

questions.text: A dead body is brought for autopsy. On examination of neck, a ligature that was present obliquely, and above the level of the thyroid was seen. The subcutaneous tissue under the mark was white and glistening. What is the cause of death?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hanging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of hanging , the ligature mark is oblique and above the thyroid , with the subcutaneous tissue under the ligature appearing white and glistening due to compression, distinguishing it from other forms of neck compression or strangulation.
  • ➤ hanging
  • ➤ oblique and above the thyroid

questions.text: All are traumatic asphyxia except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Accidental Strangulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Traumatic asphyxia results from external compression of the chest, as seen in accidents or stampedes. Strangulation, which applies pressure to the neck rather than the chest, does not fall under traumatic asphyxia.

questions.text: The below image is which kind of Asphyxia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Smothering

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Smothering is a form of asphyxia where the external air passages (mouth and nose) are obstructed, preventing breathing. This can be achieved by covering the mouth and nose, as seen in the image.

questions.text: A forensic expert is reviewing autopsy reports for a series of asphyxiation cases. In the course of this review, the expert is aware that certain methods of asphyxiation carry a higher suspicion of homicidal intent due to their nature and the circumstances under which they typically occur. Which method of asphyxiation listed below is almost always considered to be homicidal in nature?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gagging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gagging as an asphyxial death mechanism that is almost always associated with homicidal actions due to its forced nature.
  • ➤ Gagging as an asphyxial death mechanism that is almost always associated with homicidal actions due to its forced nature.

questions.text: The image below is diagnostic of death due to:
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Drowning

questions.text: The phenomenon known as "Washerwoman's hand," characterized by wrinkled and pale appearance of the skin on the hands and feet, is most indicative of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Submersion in water

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ "Washerwoman's hand" is a sign of submersion in water and occurs due to the skin's prolonged exposure to moisture. It is important to distinguish this phenomenon as a result of water exposure, not necessarily as an indication of drowning or decomposition.
  • ➤ "Washerwoman's hand"

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about fresh water drowning:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypovolemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In freshwater drowning , the primary changes include hypervolemia , hemolysis , hyperkalemia , and the risk of ventricular fibrillation . Hypovolemia is not a characteristic of freshwater drowning and is therefore the incorrect statement in this context.
  • ➤ freshwater drowning
  • ➤ hypervolemia
  • ➤ hemolysis
  • ➤ hyperkalemia
  • ➤ ventricular fibrillation
  • ➤ Hypovolemia

questions.text: A 22-year-old mountaineer presents to the emergency department after being rescued from high altitude with complaints of severe pain and numbness in his face following exposure to extreme cold and windy conditions. He reports that the symptoms started a few hours after his protective gear was dislodged by strong winds. Physical examination reveals hard, cold, and pale areas on his face. The medical officer is concerned about frostbite and considers which part of the patient's face is most susceptible to this condition. Which part of the face is most commonly affected by frostbite in these conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nose

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The lips can be affected by cold weather, leading to chapping and frostnip, but they are less likely than the nose to develop severe frostbite due to being less prominent and often protected by being covered or by breathing.
  • • Option A.
  • • lips can be affected by cold weather, leading to chapping and frostnip, but they are less likely than the nose to develop severe frostbite
  • • Option C. The cheeks are also susceptible to frostbite, but their larger surface area and blood supply generally afford slightly better protection compared to the nose.
  • • Option C.
  • • cheeks are also susceptible to frostbite, but their larger surface area and blood supply generally afford slightly better protection
  • • Option D. Hair cannot develop frostbite as it is composed of keratin and does not contain living tissue or water that can freeze.
  • • Option D.
  • • Hair cannot develop frostbite as it is composed of keratin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Frostbite is most likely to affect body parts that are farther away from the body core and, therefore, have less blood flow . These include Nose, Ear, Fingers (and Hands), Toes (and Feet).
  • ➤ Frostbite
  • ➤ affect body parts that are farther away from the body core
  • ➤ have less blood flow
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 317-318
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ - Reddy 33/e. Pg 317-318

questions.text: Police officers found a completely burnt dead body of a person in a forest. They suspect that someone might have killed him and later burnt the dead body to avoid identification. Doctor while conducting the post-mortem, found a significant finding in the larynx as shown below. This is suggestive of?
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Antemortem Burns

questions.text: The following is a victim of a firearm injury. What is the suspected distance of the shot?
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Intermediate range

questions.text: Characteristic of Joule burn include all except?

options.label: C
options.text: Pale raised skin at the margins

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Joule burn is Hyperaemic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Joule burns are typically pale with minimal hyperemia due to vasospasm caused by the intense heat of electrical contact. These burns are often seen at the point of contact with the electrical source and may form a shallow crater with raised pale margins .
  • ➤ Joule burns
  • ➤ pale
  • ➤ vasospasm
  • ➤ point of contact
  • ➤ shallow crater
  • ➤ raised pale margins

questions.text: A 45-year-old electrician is brought to the emergency department after sustaining injuries from a high-voltage electrical line during work. Upon examination, the patient has areas of skin that are leathery with a distinctive pattern that resembles crocodile skin. The areas are primarily localized along the pathway of the current across his body. The medical officer is discussing the case with residents and asks them to identify the condition that typically presents this type of skin appearance. What is the "crocodile skin" appearance commonly associated with?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) High voltage burns

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Drowning does not result in such patterns on the skin ; changes related to drowning include wrinkling or washing away of the superficial skin layers.
  • • Option A.
  • • Drowning does not result in such patterns on the skin
  • • Option B. Mummification refers to the dehydration of the body after death , leading to dry, shrunken, and leathery skin.
  • • Option B.
  • • Mummification refers to the dehydration of the body after death
  • • Option D. Electric shocks can cause a variety of skin appearances depending on the voltage , but the specific "crocodile skin" appearance is typically associated with high voltage injuries.
  • • Option D.
  • • Electric shocks can cause a variety of skin appearances depending on the voltage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Crocodile skin appearance is a kind of exogenous burns seen due to Electric current in high voltage sources when there is no direct contact with body. The term electric shock is used when the person touches an electrical source , whereas, Crocodile skin appearance occurs when the person is near the high voltage source but not in direct contact.
  • ➤ Crocodile skin appearance is a kind of exogenous burns seen due to Electric current in high voltage sources when there is no direct contact with body.
  • ➤ touches an electrical source
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 330-331
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ - Reddy 33/e. Pg 330-331

questions.text: What is true about the image below?

options.label: A
options.text: They are caused by Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells along the path of electric current.

options.label: B
options.text: They indicate the path taken by the discharge along the major blood vessels

options.label: D
options.text: They gradually fade within 24 – 48 hours if the person is dead

questions.correct_answer: A. They are caused by Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells along the path of electric current.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) They are caused by Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells along the path of electric current.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lichtenberg figures are caused by the staining of superficial tissues with hemoglobin after electrical injury from a lightning strike. These patterns are not burns and follow the path of microvasculature, not major blood vessels.

questions.text: The below image shows:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Heat stiffening

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize that the pugilistic or boxer's attitude is caused by heat stiffening , where intense heat leads to muscle contraction, creating a flexed posture often seen in burn victims.
  • ➤ pugilistic or boxer's attitude
  • ➤ heat stiffening

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who was working in the fields all day, collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. His skin was dry and hot, face was flushed, pulse was fast and thready. Which of the following symptoms are least likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Sweating

questions.text: In the assessment of traumatic injuries, it is crucial to understand the likelihood of various types of wounds occurring at different anatomical sites. Incised-looking lacerated wounds, which are typically caused by blunt force over bony prominences, present a unique diagnostic challenge. Given the nature of these wounds and the characteristics of different body areas, which of the following anatomical sites is the least likely to exhibit an incised-looking lacerated wound?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Abdomen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Shin of tibia - The shin, with its bony prominence , is a common site for incised-looking lacerated wounds due to blunt force trauma.
  • • Option A. Shin of tibia
  • • with its bony prominence
  • • common site for incised-looking lacerated wounds
  • • Option B. Scalp - The scalp is another common area for such wounds , as the skin is tightly adherent to the skull , facilitating a split that resembles an incised wound.
  • • Option B. Scalp
  • • another common area for such wounds
  • • skin is tightly adherent to the skull
  • • Option C. Chin - Similar to the shin and scalp, the chin's bony prominence makes it a more likely site for incised-looking lacerated wounds.
  • • Option C. Chin
  • • the chin's bony prominence makes it a more likely site for incised-looking lacerated wounds.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Incised-looking lacerated wounds are more likely to occur in areas with bony prominences , such as the shin of the tibia, scalp, and chin , and less likely in softer, less prominent areas like the abdomen
  • ➤ Incised-looking lacerated wounds
  • ➤ areas with bony prominences
  • ➤ shin of the tibia, scalp, and chin
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 191
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Reddy 33/e. Pg 191

questions.text: A suspect is apprehended for engaging in intrusive behavior involving the secret observation of individuals in private settings without their consent, with the intention of obtaining sexual pleasure. What term best describes this behavior?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Voyeurism

questions.text: A Police officer brings a 15-year-old male child to the doctor for medical examination. The mother of the child gives the history that his uncle has been threatening and sexually assaulting him for the past 2 years, which she came to know now and complained to the police. After doing the complete examination, the doctor examines the anus, which shows features in the picture below. This is suggestive of?
questions.correct_answer: B. Repeated anal sex with child
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Repeated anal sex with child

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Recent anal sex with child : Incorrect, as the presence of penile secretion (semen) is the main indicators for recent anal sex . These are not present in the image provided.
  • • Option A
  • • Recent anal sex with child
  • • presence of penile secretion
  • • is the main indicators for recent anal sex
  • • Option C . First anal sex with child : Incorrect, because in non- habitual victim, injuries like abrasions, bruises and lacerations are present at anal opening but in the image these are absent.
  • • Option C
  • • First anal sex with child
  • • non- habitual victim, injuries like abrasions, bruises and lacerations are present at anal opening
  • • Option D . Normal anus : Is not the answer because normal anus looks like as below
  • • Option D
  • • Normal anus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sodomy is the anal intercourse between two males (homosexual sodomy) or between a male and a female (heterosexual sodomy).
  • ➤ Sodomy is the anal intercourse between two males
  • ➤ between a male and a female
  • ➤ It is called gerontophilia when the passive agent is an adult , and paederasty , when the passive agent is a child , who is known as catamite . A pedophile is an adult who repeatedly engages in sexual activities with children .
  • ➤ gerontophilia when the passive agent is an adult
  • ➤ paederasty
  • ➤ when the passive agent is a child
  • ➤ catamite
  • ➤ pedophile is an adult who repeatedly engages in sexual activities with children
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 427
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Reddy 33/e. Pg 427

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual diagnosed with schizophrenia commits an act that would otherwise be considered a criminal offense. The act was committed during a period of acute psychotic episode. The individual's medical history indicates sporadic adherence to prescribed antipsychotic medication. The prosecution has charged the individual with the offense. Based on the provided information, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the criminal responsibility of mentally ill?

options.label: A
options.text: The accused will be responsible since the act was committed while not adhering to prescribed medication.

options.label: B
options.text: The accused will not be responsible as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.

options.label: C
options.text: The accused will be responsible due to the sporadic nature of the individual's symptoms.

options.label: D
options.text: The accused will not be responsible only if the act was committed during a state of complete unconsciousness.

questions.correct_answer: B. The accused will not be responsible as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The accused will not be responsible as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that under legal provisions like Section 84 IPC or 22 BNS , individuals who commit offenses during acute psychotic episodes may not be held criminally responsible, as their mental state prevents them from comprehending the nature of their actions. Medication adherence is not a determining factor in criminal responsibility.
  • ➤ Section 84 IPC
  • ➤ 22 BNS

questions.text: Psychological autopsy is?

options.label: A
options.text: Autopsy of brain and spinal cord

options.label: B
options.text: To inquire about the psychiatric illnesses of the deceased

options.label: C
options.text: Assessment of the mental state of deceased person before death

questions.correct_answer: C. Assessment of the mental state of deceased person before death
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Assessment of the mental state of deceased person before death

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A psychological autopsy is used to reconstruct the mental state of a deceased person prior to death, especially when the death is suspected to be a suicide or involves other unclear circumstances. It is a tool for understanding the psychological and social factors leading up to death.

questions.text: During a high-profile court case, the jury is presented with the situation of a 40-year-old university professor who has been charged with the serious assault of a colleague. It comes to light during the trial that the professor has been battling untreated schizophrenia, characterized by profound auditory hallucinations and delusions. On the day in question, he was under the delusion that his colleague was a covert agent sent to harm him, leading to the assault. The defence argues that the professor's mental state at the time of the incident rendered him incapable of understanding his actions' nature or distinguishing right from wrong. Given these circumstances and applying the Legal Test of Insanity, how should the professor's criminal responsibility be assessed?

options.label: A
options.text: He is criminally responsible because he was conscious of his physical actions during the assault.

options.label: B
options.text: He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to comprehend the true nature of his actions because of his delusional perception.

options.label: C
options.text: He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to control his actions due to his underlying schizophrenia.

options.label: D
options.text: He is criminally responsible because his mental illness does not excuse violent behavior.

questions.correct_answer: B. He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to comprehend the true nature of his actions because of his delusional perception.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to comprehend the true nature of his actions because of his delusional perception.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of insanity defense , the key factor is whether the individual was able to understand the nature of their actions and distinguish between right and wrong at the time of the offense. Delusions that distort a person’s perception of reality, as in this case, can render them not criminally responsible under the M'Naghten Rule .
  • ➤ insanity defense
  • ➤ understand the nature of their actions
  • ➤ right and wrong
  • ➤ not criminally responsible
  • ➤ M'Naghten Rule

questions.text: A forensic expert is summoned upon to deliver expert testimony in a notable legal case involving a 35-year-old male defendant accused of engaging in onanism in a setting that has raised public and legal concerns. The court is seeking clarity on accused behavior viewed from a forensic and medicolegal standpoint, considering the act's context and its implications for public decency and legal boundaries. How should the forensic expert classify the act of onanism in this scenario, given the complexities of legal and social standards?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Perversion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . A natural sexual offense would imply an act that is inherently wrong by natural standards , which does not accurately describe masturbation.
  • • Option A
  • • natural sexual offense
  • • act that is inherently wrong by natural standards
  • • Option B . An unnatural sexual offense typically refers to sexual acts that deviate from societal norms to an extreme extent , often involving non-consenting parties, which is not applicable to private masturbation.
  • • Option B
  • • unnatural sexual offense
  • • sexual acts that deviate from societal norms to an extreme extent
  • • Option D . Indecent assault generally involves non-consensual contact with another individual , which is not the case with private acts of masturbation but could apply to the public behavior or distribution of content without consent.
  • • Option D
  • • Indecent assault generally involves non-consensual contact with another individual

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Masturbation/Onanism - Deliberate self-stimulation which results in sexual arousal. It is an offence when practiced openly, e.g. in telephone booths, bus or toilets.
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 432
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Reddy 33/e. Pg 432

questions.text: A forensic expert is reviewing a case involving a young child brought by concerned guardians. The child exhibited distress and mild physical symptoms suggesting possible sexual abuse. During the examination, he noted the absence of hymenal rupture, which raised questions about the assessment's findings among the para clinical staff. The forensic expert, called upon to provide clarity, emphasized a key anatomical feature of the hymen in prepubertal children that might explain the lack of expected trauma signs. What is the primary reason the hymen in children might not show rupture in suspected cases of sexual assault?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Deep seated

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • The hymen in prepubertal children is often deep seated , meaning it is positioned deeper within the vaginal vestibule compared to that in adolescents and adults . This anatomical positioning can provide a degree of protection against trauma , potentially explaining the absence of hymenal rupture even in the context of suspected sexual assault.
  • • hymen in prepubertal children is often deep seated
  • • it is positioned deeper within the vaginal vestibule compared to that in adolescents and adults
  • • degree of protection against trauma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a young child, there are few or no signs of general violence , for the child usually has no idea of what is happening and also incapable of resisting. As the hymen is deeply situated and the vagina is less capacious, it is impossible for penetration of the penis to take place .
  • ➤ In a young child,
  • ➤ few or no signs of general violence
  • ➤ hymen is deeply situated and the vagina is less capacious, it is impossible for penetration of the penis to take place
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 421
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Reddy 33/e. Pg 421
